bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Leandro W. Tocantins, January 17, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Tocantins that his presence as a representative of the Jefferson Medical College at the Camp Lazear dedication was appreciated. He is sending him a letter and photographs related to the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Leandro W. Tocantins, January 17, 1953
div1.opener:
January 17, 1953
Dr. L. M. Tocantins
The Jefferson Medical College of Philadelphia
1025 Walnut Street
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
My dear Doctor Tocantins:
div1.p:
Because of my professional obligations and the holiday activities, I have
been delayed in preparing the enclosed long personal letter written for
the relatives of those honored at the dedication of Camp Lazear. I thought
you might like a copy and perhaps Dean Bennett or Mr. Rake might like to see
a copy (If they want their own copies we can have one or two more made up
as they are ozalid copies.).

I received from Dean Bennett a check for $18 which represents an over-
payment of $3.00 I am sending him my own personal check for that amount.

I am very glad indeed for the participation of Jefferson Medical College
in this affair. I am most happy that Dean Bennett asked you to go and that
you were able to accept. Your presence was much more important than per-
haps you realized as I think you will gather from the tenor of my letter.

Two or three photographs were taken by news photographers of you, laying
the wreath and speaking. I have copies. After you left, many other
photographs were given to me so that I have quite a few, but an incomplete
collection of photographs of the whole ceremony. Doctor Nogueira promised
to borrow the films from the news photographers and send them to me shortly
if you wish further copies. I do hope you enjoyed your visit and it was
certainly grand that you were there. The Cubans certainly appreciated
it.

Although we can provide an extra copy or two of the letter enclosed, I have
no further copies of the newspaper clippings; therefore you may wish to show
these to Dean Bennett and/or Mr. Rake. Should you wish to write up some-
thing about the dedication for the Jefferson Medical Alumni, please feel
free to borrow anything you want from my letter without acknowledgement.

I would appreciate it greatly if you would send me a copy of your speech.
Although you gave it informally, I suspect you had something in the way of
notes or could reconstruct it. I should like very much to have this.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
